byline.contributor: David D. Kirkpatrick reported from Misurata; Ben Hubbard from Sanliurfa, Turkey; and Eric Schmitt from Washington. Suliman Ali Zway contributed reporting from Misurata and Tripoli, Libya, and an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria.
byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK, BEN HUBBARD and ERIC SCHMITT

abstract: Islamic State colony in Surt, Libya, is only affiliate colony directly managed by insurgent group's leaders, forming strategic hub and important fallback location as group comes under pressure in Iraq and Syria; counterterrorism officials express concern ISIS may be preparing city as place to retreat to and continue its activities in if it is driven from its original territories (Series: State of Terror).
lead_paragraph: The Mediterranean port city of Surt has become an actively managed colony of the Islamic State, which has come under growing military and economic pressure in Syria and Iraq.

headline.main: ISIS’ Grip on Libyan City Gives It a Fallback Option
headline.print_headline: ISIS’ Grip on Libyan City Gives It a Fallback Option

snippet: The Mediterranean port city of Surt has become an actively managed colony of the Islamic State, which has come under growing military and economic pressure in Syria and Iraq.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
